page.lettertext:
fol.305r
Belgia: 1590: Octob
r
.
Belgia 1590 28 Octo
b
to my L. Trea
s
May yt please yo
r
L. 4 daies past I Rxd yo
r
L. letter
of the 9 of this moneth, wh
r
in yo
u
require that the man
of
Donkerk
should be sent unto yo
u
, I do not dout but
yo
u
have since und
r
stood that
Co. Maurice
hath attempted
that surprise & failed of his purpose, yo
r
L. may conjecture
that his Intention th
r
in was knowen before to the
Councell
of state
, & might have bin by mee adv
r
tized home.
But I do assure yo
r
L. yt is an exploit w
ch
the Co.
und
r
tooke up
o
e soddain & concealed yt altogeth
r
from the
Councell of state, for w
ch
they dislike his
ceeding very
much, & have resolved to admonish him of yt publickely.
Moreover, yt may seeme unto yo
u
that the
ties heer, by
whom that ouverture was made unto mee, have not dealt
so syncerely, as they should, but im
ted theyr secret
aswell to
e Co. as to mee, but as I writt to yo
r
L. the
21 of Sep
t
the Co. had some secret informa
o
n by some
other meanes of
e state of
e Towne, & of
e weakenes
of yt there, where hee thought to assault yt. And
as for those
t
are heer, by whom that matter at fyrst
was desclosed unto mee, by all
e tokens that I can see
w
ch
are also confirmed by theyr solemne
testa
o
ns, being
men of an honest & upright caringe, & so reputed
where they live, I cannot anie waie conceave anie litell
suspition of theyr double dealing. Besydes it is
manifest by the very course w
ch
was held by the Count
in his sailing, & marching w
th
out respect at midday
& in sight of
e ennemy, wh
r
of I am
swaded yo
u
are
fully adv
r
tized by those that were p
nt
, that hee was
holpen in nothing by the foresayd
ties. For they
do both condemn him for his ill conduction, & affirme
w
th
all, w
ch
I do also gues by oth
r
circumstances
that hee had no Intelligence at all of
e entrance by
the water gate, w
ch
by theyr declaration was the
principall place, for the execution of hys purpose,
& might have bin possessed very easilie w
th
forces
fol.305v
Belgia: 1590: Octob
r
.
out of
England
w
th
out suspition of
e ennemy
M
r
Gilpin
to whom of late I im
ted
e matter
seemed to learne of
S
r
Francis Vere
in
Zeeland
w
ch
hee writ from thence as he saith to yo
r
L.
that
e said entraunce by water was
vided for
by
e Ennemie. Howbeyt I have as of my self
this daie moved divers questions a far of to
e
Count about
e place by circumstance to feele whether
his intelligence were
e same, as I had Receaved,
& what conceat hee had of yt, but yt appeared by
his awnswers, that hee knoweth nothing, but very
confusedly & not to
e effect as I had
posed.
This attempt of Co. Maurice being frustrate, becaus
yt may be p
r
sumed that the ennemy will sound &
fortifie the weakest places of
e Towne I cannot
conjecture, that her
Ma
ty
is desyrous that I should
send those
sons into England, for whom yo
r
L.
hath written. Nevertheles not to give
e matter over
till I see yt out of hope, nor to leave any thing
unassayed, w
ch
may w
th
facility be furder
fourmed
I have heer agreed w
th
e pensionar of Dunkerk
that he shall p
nt
ly repaire into Zeeland to his
fellow
e Eschevin, & that both of them together
shall send some honest trusty
son to Dunkerk
(for whom they may
cure some passeport of course
for the ennemy, & give him instruciton to learn the
ticular truthe of such point
as shalbee delivered
unto him. Chiefly to ob
s
ve how all thing
stand
about
e watergate, & what oth
r
altera
o
n is made
in
e Town. Upon
e retourn of this messenger
according to
e likelihood of that report, that hee
shall make, I will either staie or send
e
ties
them selves unto yo
u
, who are also willing unto yt
fol.306r
Belgia: 1590: Oc
t
.
yf all continew as yt was. & will alwaies adventure
theyr owne
sons in the greatest place of daunger
in
fourmance of
e enterprise. For lack of a
cypher I can hardly write of this matter, to
bee well understood but in open termes, w
ch
I feare to doe
e lesse, because I cannot yet
complaine, that any letter of mine hath miscaryed
hethertoo/. I know not as yet
when too looke for any awnswer to o
r
last
positions, for I cannot
ceave by any conjecture
that they had ever other purpose, or have at this
present, then to temporize, & to attend a good houre
in
e affaires of
Fraunce
, w
ch
growing to theyr liking
I am c
r
tainly
swaded they will give her Ma
ty
but a careles & an insolent awnswer, & in that respect
I should think yt very nedefull (w
ch
I speak w
th
submission
to yo
r
L. correction) that therafter as the King shall prosper
in his actions, her Ma
ties
garrisons in
e cautionary townes
might bee carefully reaosned. For I see this people
in all their dealing
are very heady & inconstant &
quickly drawen to do any thing by those that manege
theyr affaires, of w
ch
e most at this p
nt
are
neither well enclined to her Ma
tyes
causes, & endevo
r
to exclude her fr
o
all her interest among th
e
. There
are some of North
Holland
, that are unknowne unto
mee, but as I am c
r
tified by oth
r
men of good q
lity
& wishing well unto her Hig
nes
who have caused mee of
late to bee secretly advertized, that for spetiall occasions
w
ch
they will not disclose yt behoveth her Ma
ty
to look
unto
Flushing
. I have had
e like warning by oth
r
men
heer, who signify unto mee that yt hath bin debated by
some principall
sons in theyr private meeting
, w
ch
waie they might be able, w
ch
they make very easye, to
thrust the English out of Flushing. For mine owne opinion
in
ticular I can by no meanes imagine, that there is
any practise as yet to attempt yt actually, but yet I
fol.306v
Belgia 1590 [October]
take such discowrses to be theyr preparatives. & yf yt
go well w
th
e
K. of Fraunce
, wh
r
by ther fear of
e ennemy may bee more diminished, they were
hardly to be trusted. To provide for
e worst I
thought yt very requesyt, to make some intimation to
e
Gouverno
r
of Flushing
of the caveat
that I
Rxd. The demand of
Coronell Stuart
, w
ch
her
Ma
ty
recommendeth by yo
r
L. severall l
res
is sollicited
heer by one
M
r
John Skeyn
a scottish gentleman,
whom
e
K.
had very lately employed into
Denmarke
& hath charged going home to deale w
th
e states
in that cause. The first of yo
r
L. letters astouching
M
r
Stewart was delivered to mee 3 daies past by
M
r
Skeyne him self, to whom in respect of my
ticular endevours, I will not faile to give
good satisfaction, & yet remember w
th
all what
yo
r
L. doth advise yn yo
r
next letter after, I
have already recommended the su it in her Ma
ties
name
to
e states, whom I find very greatly
plexed
by reason of
e letters of Mart. Howbeyt for
ought I can
ceave they will never yeeld to such a
president as to paie the debte of oth
r
provinces.
There are many marchant
newly com heth
r
both
from
middelboro
&
Amsterdam
, w
ch
exlaim against
o
r
nation very bitterly in ev
r
y place where they come
for empeaching theyr traffique w
th
Spaine
. They have
addressed theyr complaint
to
e
generall States
, who
as it seemeth at this p
nt
, are half resolved to send
certain deputies to her Ma
ty
about yt.
And so
I take my humble leave.
Hagh
. Oct
o
28
A
o
1590.
